.
Protection at Lower Than the Current Evaluation
In some cases, the current evaluation may not have been in effect for 20 years, but the evaluation has been at a lower level for the requisite 20-year period.
In such cases, the current evaluation is not the protected evaluation, but the lower evaluation is protected.  A reduction can be accomplished but not below the protected evaluation.
Example
:  A Veteran is SC for a knee strain evaluated as 30-percent disabling.  Current medical evidence supports a 10-percent evaluation.  Assume compliance with
38 CFR 3.105
and
38 CFR 3.344
.  The
Codesheet
shows the following evaluation history:
0 percent, in place for 30 years
10 percent, in place for 25 years
20 percent, in place for 21 years
30 percent, in place for 19 years and one month
The 30-percent evaluation has not been in effect for the requisite 20-year period.  Therefore, it is not and will not be protected for the purpose of the proposed reduction.  The highest protected evaluation is the 20-percent evaluation, since it was in effect for at least 20 years.  Although the facts support only a 10-percent evaluation, the maximum reduction possible is to 20 percent.
